channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hezbollah in Lebanon Is Attacked From Syria
item.description: It was not the first strike on a hub of Hezbollah, whose fighters are allied with the Syrian president, but it could be the most provocative yet.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HALA DROUBI

item.title: Angry Protests Grow in Turkey as Police Continue Crackdown
item.description: The prime minister called for a halt to the protests and said redevelopment of a park in Istanbul’s Taksim Square would move ahead.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: A riot police officer fired a tear gas grenade on Saturday to disperse demonstrators during a rally against the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Istanbul.

item.title: Tokhtakhounov Says Criminal Charges Are Just a Misunderstanding
item.description: American authorities view Alimzhan T. Tokhtakhounov as a leading figure in Russian organized crime. They are mistaken, he says.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and JAMES GLANZ
item.media:credit: Oksana Yushko for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I am not bad, like you think,” says Alimzhan T. Tokhtakhounov. “I am not the Mafia, I am not a bandit.” He faces charges in the United States, but not in Russia.

item.title: Hagel Warns China on ‘Growing Threat’ of Cyberattacks
item.description: Speaking in Singapore, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel said the United States was concerned about intrusions linked to the Chinese government and military.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel spoke at the International Institute for Strategic Studies Shangri-la Dialogue on Saturday in Singapore.

item.title: Grief and Political Reverberations After British Soldier’s Killing
item.description: The killing of Lee Rigby has shocked Britain as few things have in recent memory, with the political reverberations continuing for the government of Prime Minister David Cameron.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: Tributes lined the sidewalk outside the barracks where the soldier Lee Rigby, 25, was killed.

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 1
item.description: German population fears; identifying factory fire’s victims; unemployment rises in Euro zone; and deflation may be ending in Japan.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Taslima Akhter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hasibul Islam Reaz, 10, has provided blood for efforts to identify his father, who worked in a factory building that collapsed.

item.title: U.S. Targets Iran’s Petrochemical Industry
item.description: In addition to blacklisting Iranian petrochemical companies for the first time, the Obama administration punished businesses in other countries that help Iran evade oil sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Prosecutors Investigate Spending of Government Funds
item.description: Prosecutors in Georgia are investigating allegations that President Mikheil Saakashvili misused government funds, including more than $11,000 for Botox injections.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: U.S. Olympic Leaders Mending Ties With I.O.C.
item.description: The United States Olympic Committee has made changes to satisfy the International Olympic Committee, bolstering a chance to host the 2024 Summer Games.
item.dc:creator: By MARY PILON

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: A Court Seeks Qaddafi’s Son
item.description: Judges at the International Criminal Court ruled that Libya must hand over Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, a son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to the court.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Science and Health: Circumcision Device Approved by World Health Organization
item.description: A nonsurgical circumcision device that relies on a rubber band was approved by the World Health Organization, opening the way for its widespread use in Africa.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Elections Postponed
item.description: Lebanon’s Parliament voted to delay elections, which had been scheduled to take place on June 16, for at least 17 months.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Court Speeds Up Vote
item.description: Zimbabwe’s highest court ordered that national elections be held before the end of July, speeding up the expected timetable to choose a new Parliament and hold a presidential vote.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: One Obstacle Won’t Budge in Japan’s Fight With Deflation
item.description: The Japanese government has made stemming deflation a priority, but its efforts so far have not affected everyday items, like a can of soda.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Vending machines in Japan have become a stubborn barometer of the country’s struggle against deflation.

item.title: Michigan Woman Killed in Syria War, Reports Say
item.description: The family and a close friend of Nicole Mansfield said the news delivered by the F.B.I. that she had been in Syria and was killed came as a shock.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON
item.media:credit: Jake May/The Flint Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Carole Mansfield at her home in Burton, Mich., after news that her granddaughter Nicole Mansfield had been killed in Syria.

item.title: U.S. Olympic Leaders Mending Ties With I.O.C.
item.description: The United States Olympic Committee has made changes to satisfy the International Olympic Committee, bolstering a chance to host the 2024 Summer Games.
item.dc:creator: By MARY PILON

item.title: Concern Grows After Group Disappears in Mexico City
item.description: Eleven young people — seven men and four women — never made it home after a night out in the trendy Zona Rosa neighborhood of the capital.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY
item.media:description: A man looked at posters outside a bar in Mexico City of a group of 11 people that recently disappeared after a night partying.

item.title: Kerry Castigates Russia Over Syria-Bound Missiles
item.description: It was Secretary of State John Kerry’s most pointed criticism so far of Russia’s supply of weaponry to the Syrian government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry suggested that Russia’s continued sale of weaponry to Mr. Assad’s government called into question its commitment to the political process in Syria.

item.title: British Columbia Opposes Planned Oil Sands Pipeline
item.description: Environmental groups said that British Columbia, which has been concerned about spills, has probably doomed the pipeline.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Taliban Deny Responsibility for Attack on Red Cross
item.description: The Taliban said they had no part in the assault this week on the offices of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, noting their previous support for the group.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: U.N. Panel Criticizes Russia for Prosecuting Rights Groups
item.description: The chairman of the United Nations Committee Against Torture said legal proceedings had begun against two groups because of reports they sent to the panel.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Economist Sergei Guriev Doesn’t Plan Return to Russia Soon
item.description: Sergei M. Guriev, now teaching at an elite Paris university, said investigators demanded that he surrender five years’ worth of e-mails and submit to searches.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Yekaterina Shtukina/RIA Novosti Kremlin, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sergei Guriev attended a meeting in Moscow in July of last year.

item.title: Amid Recession and Rising Joblessness, Greeks Fall Prey to Employment Swindles
item.description: Authorities say criminals are busy preying on increasingly desperate Greeks facing a deepening recession and a rising unemployment rate.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Small Agreements Between France and Germany Mask Larger Concerns
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany tried to repair a relationship with France, but doubts remained about President François Hollande’s resolve to make tough economic decisions.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President François Hollande of France in Paris on Thursday, after they agreed on a common approach to the next European Union meeting.
